Step.name: Welcome to iS² Training
Step.html:
Welcome to iS² Training

The iS² Project is a multi-year strategic initiative designed to improve financial controls and administrative services across campus. The project’s vision is to build a customer-oriented organization that delivers high quality, efficient and effective administrative services that enable the U of C to be a recognized leader among academic institutions.

This training is designed to address improvements to Processes and Systems (PeopleSoft) business processes. These improvements were implemented based on input from external sources - including Tri-Council and the Office of the Auditor General of Alberta - as well as from internal U of C needs, such as creating opportunities for cost-savings and streamlining administrative services.

Information conveyed in this training is effective August 2, 2011.

Step.name: iS² Project Rationale
Step.html:
The University of Calgary’s ability to continue to attract high-quality faculty, staff, students, and public and private funds is dependent on confidence in the university’s management and operation. This training is designed to help enable the University of Calgary to be a recognized leader among academic institutions by:

•Empowering our people

•Creating a culture of accountability and excellence

•Engaging with our community

•Believing in the value of service

•Working together as “One University”.

Step.name: Role Mapping and Changes to Processes & Systems
Step.html:
Specific Processes & Systems (i.e. PeopleSoft) related changes identified in the iS² Project will impact how work is done at the University of Calgary. You have been identified through Role Mapping to receive this training specific to your role - the skills and knowledge you require to perform the business process(es) for which you are responsible.

Role Mapping identifies an employee’s responsibilities and grants them access within PeopleSoft based on appropriate combinations of IRAP (initiator; reviewer; approver; or processor) roles within a specific function. For example, a staff or faculty member may be able to initiate the process to buy something, but that same individual may not be able to approve the expense.

Step.name: Delegation of Authority Policy
Step.html:
To ensure the university maintains this commitment to the high standard of quality financial management, the Delegation of Authority (DOA) Policy was enacted at the university in December 2010.

The Delegation of Authority Policy defines accountabilities and authorities related to management of the university’s resources; including financial planning and management of Operating, Capital and Research dollars. The DOA Policy also sets rules for who has

•Authority: the right to make decisions;

•Accountability: the responsibility for executing appropriate decisions; and

•Sub-delegation: authority which can and cannot be delegated to subordinates.

Step.name: Signing Authority Matrix (SAM)
Step.html:
The Signing Authority Matrix (SAM) supports the Delegation of Authority (DOA) Policy by identifying which employee positions (manager, supervisor, research supervisor, etc) can make certain decisions, up to a maximum dollar limit. The SAM - applicable to Finance, Procurement and HR activities - outlines the delegation of authorities from the president and vice-presidents:

•Decision authority: the right to make decisions over allocation of university resources including expenditures to approve, parameters for hiring people, or expenses to approval limits; and

•Transaction authority: the right to complete the purchase of the item, or sign the contract.

Step.name: An Example
Step.html:
The following process, purchasing photocopier paper, is one small example of how the DOA Policy, SAM and Role Mapping work together to instill confidence and provide effective and efficient management and operation.

Background

The department head of a faculty needs to purchase photocopier paper for multi-purpose use.

Applying the Three Concepts

•The Delegation of Authority (DOA) states that the Provost is accountable for establishing standard processes to allocate resources;

•The Provost also has the authority to make decisions with respect to resources allocation within the budget allocation and in accordance with university policy. That authority is then sub-delegated through the Signing Authority Matrix (SAM);

•The Deans have accountability for their faculties. Through the SAM, the Deans are also granted a certain level of authority over expenditures within their budgets;

•In turn, the Deans have sub-delegated accountability and authority, within a dollar limit, to their department heads. In the faculty requiring the purchase of photocopier paper, the department head prefers that his assistant order the reams of paper;

•Through role mapping, the assistant has been granted access to the purchase requisition screen in PeopleSoft and can initiate the transaction;

•Once initiated, the requisition flows through the automated approval process to the department head, as the Dept ID Budget Owner;

•The Dept ID Budget Owner approves the expenditure and The approved request is then routed to Supply Chain Management who processes the request.
